Addressed comments. I'll fix the conflicts and add benchmark results soon.

How about making the response context thread-safe?

Currently, the response context is returned as an HTTP header, so it should be "finalized" after `QueryRunner.run` returns, _before_ iteration over the Sequence. But it might be more useful to allow it to be finalized _after_ iteration. #3319 and #3323 are considering changing the context return mechanism to allow this.

also, please keep in mind that stuff in responseContext generated on historicals is transferred to brokers (ok, its kinda broken right now due to the header length limits but #3323 would fix that) , so it shouldn't have too much irrelevant stuff that does not need to be sent across.
goal of responseContext is to be able to pass through query execution contextual information to the end-user.
50+% improvement sounds great to me

Here is a result of simple benchmark. 

* 2 filters for ```dimUniform``` and ```dimHyperUnique``` dimensions.
  * Each filter has 0.1 selectivity.
  * The cardinality of both dimensions is 100,000.

*With concise bitmap*
```
cursorBased

SearchBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex   750000              1            750000           basic.B  avgt   25  242133.054 ± 7486.306  us/op
```

* Concise bitmap: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1nVoDMmBHqCyHfYF9pmjHLD02nkPKiV27xXj0VcyTHkQ/pubchart?oid=943815226&format=interactive
* Roaring bitmap: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1nVoDMmBHqCyHfYF9pmjHLD02nkPKiV27xXj0VcyTHkQ/pubchart?oid=300370571&format=interactive

```Auto strategy``` is little bit slower than ```Cursor-based strategy```. I suppose ```Auto strategy``` calls ```IndexOnlyStrategy.makeTimeFilteredBitmap()``` internally and this makes the difference.
@dgolitsyn This seems to conflict with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3664

I looked into this a bit more and it looks like the problem is that Calcite 1.10.0 depends on avatica-1.8.0 which includes non-relocated Jackson classes. This is bad because those classes will get loaded by all of Druid instead of the Jackson classes we actually want. Calcite master (not yet released) depends on avatica-core-1.9.0, which does not include Jackson classes, so it shouldn't have this problem. But it hasn't been released yet.

So some possible solutions:

1. Include avatica-1.8.0 in the assembly but remove the Jackson classes. Maybe it's possible to do this with some fancy Maven footwork (something involving `maven-dependency-plugin:unpack` in the distribution module)?
2. Create our own version of avatica as @joshelser suggests (I guess this means druid-avatica).
3. Wait for Calcite 1.11.0 to be released, this appears imminent and likely will be before the next Druid release (https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/calcite-dev/201612.mbox/%3C95CFECE3-A2A7-45D3-9A25-34A091EEA23C%40apache.org%3E).
4. Excluding avatica-1.8.0 and upgrading to avatica-core-1.9.0 doesn't work, since Calcite 1.10.0 won't run properly against avatica-core-1.9.0 due to some method signature changes.

I'm leaning towards (3) since that looks simplest, but if time is critical, I would be okay with (1) or (2) as well. (1) and (2) are both hacky but (1) seems better and less hacky to me.

@praveev what are your thoughts?
@joshelser, thanks for the suggestion. It seems to me this should be a lot simpler to deal with when Calcite 1.11.0 is out; does that sound right to you?

Some things to think about:

- If we do allow processing tasks to be preempted, how does resuming them work? Do they start over from the beginning or do they save state somewhere and resume where they left off? If they start from the beginning, this may involve a lot of extra work being done if tasks get preempted frequently. If they resume where they left off, we need somewhere to put their state (the contents of the processing buffer and the continuation of the processing thread) as well as some way to avoid saving too much state and running out of resources.
- Do we still have a limit on the max number of concurrent queries, which is currently given by `druid.server.http.numThreads` for most queries and `min(druid.server.http.numThreads, druid.processing.numMergeBuffers)` for groupBy v2? The max number of concurrent queries (_including_ preempted queries) needs to be limited because we don't have an infinite amount of space to store partially merged results.

Having separate thread pools (and memory pools and concurrent query limits) per priority level is one way of solving those problems. The downside is this means we need to reserve some memory for high priority queries, even when there are none happening.
@gianm do the memory pools need to be separate? Can a single common StupidPool for processing buffers be used?

There's three kinds of memory/storage pools I'm talking about:

- processing buffers (the `@Global StupidPool<ByteBuffer>`), all are the same size and at most `druid.processing.numThreads` will exist at any one time.
- merging memory (for topN and groupBy v1, it's the JVM heap; for groupBy v2, it's the `@Merging BlockingPool<ByteBuffer>`), size depends on query type and the number that exist at once depends on the number of concurrent queries.
- on-disk spilling space (only used by groupBy v2), which is limited by `druid.query.groupBy.maxOnDiskStorage` and the number of concurrent queries.

It should be fine for the processing buffers to all come from the same pool as long as some other mechanism exists to prevent unbounded numbers of buffers being allocated at the same time.

All of those three pools have the same basic problem though, which is what do you do with memory/disk resources you've allocated to a low-priority query when a high-priority query comes in. You could keep them allocated to the low-priority query, which implies you'll need to reserve some resources ahead of time for high-priority queries, otherwise there might be none left. Or you could deallocate them, which implies that low-priority queries will either get canceled or will need to re-do some or all of their work. Or you could save them to disk and restore them later, which works for the memory pools, but then you have to have a plan for what to do when you run out of disk space.

IMO, the simplest solution varies based on whether low or high priority queries are "normal".

If high priority queries are normal but there are a few low priority queries from time to time, then probably reserving resources for high priority queries works best: let high priority queries use _all_ memory but low priority queries only use X% of it. This means low priority queries can't use the full power of the cluster, but that's fine because most of your queries are high priority anyway.

If low priority queries are normal but there are a few high priority queries from time to time, I think de-allocating resources works best: if a high priority query comes in, let it grab resources that are currently used by a low priority query, and force that low priority query to start over when the high priority query is done. This means that some low priority queries will need to redo some work, but that's fine because there aren't that many high priority queries so this won't happen very often.

If you have a lot of both kinds of queries, that's tougher :)

Some other thoughts:

- If the expected workload involves a lot of concurrent low priority queries, you may need to tackle the query concurrency limit too, which is imposed by the jetty thread pool size: `druid.server.http.numThreads`. If those are all taken up by low priority queries, then processing pool QoS is irrelevant since the query will not even get that far. Keeping in mind that lifting this limit will create more memory pressure in terms of memory used for merging results.
- The problem is a lot simpler if you assume that memory for merging results is effectively "unlimited". Then you only have to worry about one of those three pools (the processing buffers). This is probably a valid assumption for timeseries. It may even be valid for topN if you have some reasonable limit on the number of concurrent queries and on thresholds. It is probably _not_ valid for most groupBy workloads.
@gianm 👍 to wait for calcite 1.11.0. looks like they plan to release in early Jan. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1547

> It seems to me this should be a lot simpler to deal with when Calcite 1.11.0 is out; does that sound right to you?

Yeah, this is just the inherent lag between Avatica and Calcite releases lining up. In the future, I'd like to solidify API between the two projects which should let you do things like just provide a newer version of Avatica with Calcite, not worrying about method signature changes.

I'll try to keep it in mind when we start getting RC's together for Calcite 1.11.0 and mention it again to make sure that we revisit this issue before it's released (not that we'd have to turn around and make a 1.11.1).
See discussion in #3805, we will attempt to fix this by upgrading to Calcite 1.11.0 when it comes out (release expected soon: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1547).
Thanks @joshelser and @praveev. In that case I'll close this PR and we can do a new one under #3800 when Calcite 1.11.0 is released.

Pretty bold @himanshug :)

There should be a doc change for this too, at least to javascript.md and probably a few other files. Maybe also add a property `druid.javascript.enable` so the config to enable javascript doesn't look so goofy (`druid.javascript.disable=false` is a double negative and looks weird). If you do that then there should be something verifying that the two properties match up if they're both defined.

That all being said, I'm not sure how I feel about making this change. JavaScript being off by default appeals to me because it's generally not recommended except for prototyping, and is not sandboxed at all (which, even though documented, is likely surprising to users). But I am also reticent to go buck wild with incompatible changes. I'll go along with whatever the consensus is though.

I am 👍 with the changes. I agree with Gian, I think we can just have an `enable` or `enabled `property and we can keep `getDefault()` method in addition to `getEnabled()` which would have `enable` set to `false`.

@gianm I can make all the other doc updates etc , if we conclude that it makes sense to disable javascript by default. yes, it is backward incompatible and that is why 0.10.0 would be the right time to do it.
m adding the discuss tag on it.

Out of the above two approaches, i think storing the sorted results in the cache might be better otherwise we would have to resort the results every time even if we hit the cache. 
Agreed, there will be a performance penalty, but since we disable caching of groupBy queries by default, probably its ok. 
Whatever strategy we choose we should also mention this in the groupBy docs that uncached queries are expected to become slower after caching.

Fwiw I haven't tested this, but I think things should work fine even now if caching is enabled on the historicals. They should always re-sort their by-segment results whether or not they come from the cache (this happens in mergeRunners).

So this problem is really a broker cache thing -- and it would be a shame to pay the price of sorting by-segment results when caching is enabled on the historicals, since it isn't necessary.

Part of the original intention for sending the lookups to each node was that the coordinator would not need to have any lookup extensions loaded, and would not have to have any knowledge of the implementation specifics of the lookups. Which is why the coordinator communicates to the lookup listeners and the lookup listeners do the determining of if their local state is in sync with what the coordinator says it should be.

For example, if a node responds that it  has loaded "lookup_abc", but the coordinator has a new definition for "lookup_abc", then the lookup listener is intended to make the decision on if "lookup_abc" has changed sufficiently to warrant internal action to make sure the right definition is enforced.

Having the coordinator push the intended lookup definition to the lookup listeners, and the lookup listeners keep an async state visible by further management action would make sense, and I think solve the thing you are wanting to solve here.

This might be as simple as having a version or epoch kind of indicator in the coordinator lookup push, and have some metadata visible per lookup so that the coordinator can determine the state of a lookup.

What is the purpose of the lookup listeners sending a request to the coordinator? (as opposed to the coordinator sending stuff out from its side)

@drcrallen 
design proposed does not require coordinator to have the lookup extensions loaded.

it appears you agree with bringing in asynchrony, so that is good.

now the last part is about maintaining the "current_state" at coordinator .... node to coordinator push is needed to keep the "current_state" as much up-to-date as possible to power the HTTP endpoint mentioned in requirement (1).

also, current implementation actually never asks nodes what state they are in but can be completely out of sync with reality if its previous request to the node failed or if there was leadership change etc and some drops might never happen... i think some of this is mentioned in the current docs as well.

also @cheddar pointed out that the part where node push state to coordinator.... connection can still be initiated by coordinator .... a long standing request from coordinator to node and node continues to respond on that request whenever something changes.

also, for MVP at least, I can totally do away with node->coordinator push and just have a metric publishing time taken to do the lookup mgmt loop at coordinator .... if it is under a minute then the push from node to coordinator is not necessary.
@niketh any numbers on the improvement?

The current method can get out of sync, specifically with drops as you mention ( https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2684 )

If the coordinator can't reconcile different versions of the same lookup, but *CAN* determine if a lookup is missing or superfluous (dictator mode), then it doesn't need an endpoint that nodes call back to. It can query the lookup listeners to determine what is on them and reconcile differences in things that may be missing.

I *think* dropping lookups in an eventual way is less important than ensuring: "load missing or wrong lookups NOW", please correct me if you feel otherwise, so having an asynchronous helper which is responsible for removing no longer needed lookups (optionally enabled) makes sense.
@fjy We have these changes deployed on our cluster and we found that the segments are now equally distributed instead of distributing on a single node
